) Program Goals: The goal of EP Technical’s programs is to encourage plan sponsors to voluntarily comply with the income tax laws while avoiding plan disqualiﬁcation. (

(a) in form and operation. A qualiﬁed plan is entitled to favorable tax treatment. (

) The EP Technical group managers supervise employees in EP Technical. (

) EP Technical employees work on assignments from their group managers. Employees who are appointed members of the Joint Board for the of Actuaries (“Board”) also receive work assignments from the Board. (

) An EP Technical employee who ﬁnds indications of fraud while processing a case will discuss the facts with the group manager. If the manager concurs, the EP Technical employee and their manager will contact the EP Fraud and/or the TE/GE Fraud Specialist to discuss the ﬁrst indications of fraud possible further development. If the EP Fraud SME and/or the TE/GE Fraud Specialist agree that there are sufficient indicators to warrant fraud develop- ment, they will contact the National Fraud Program Fraud Technical Advisor, and together follow the fraud development procedures prescribed in IRM
, Fraud Handbook, Recognizing and Developing Fraud. (
) EP Technical employees are responsible for following the procedures in IRM

IRS employees are prohibited from discussing taxpayer information with any who is not speciﬁcally authorized by the taxpayer unless the taxpayer is present. (

Workpapers, Conference reports and technical case history sheets; c. Any memos that reﬂect the rationale for the case result.

) This section discusses general procedures for processing letter ruling A letter ruling is a written statement that applies the tax laws or other non-tax employee beneﬁt laws to the taxpayer’s speciﬁc set of facts. (
) EP Technical processes a letter ruling only if it complies with the procedural requirements listed in Appendix E of Rev. Proc.
(See Appendix D of Rev. Proc.
for a sample private letter ruling request). (
) A taxpayer must submit a letter ruling request with the correct user fee listed Appendix A of Rev. Proc.

It may be appropriate to use expedited case handling when: i) a court or government agency has imposed a speciﬁc deadline; or ii) a transaction must be completed expeditiously to avoid an imminent business emergency, if the taxpayer can show that the deadline or business emergency and need for expedited handling resulted from circumstances that they couldn’t have reasonably anticipated or controlled.

When scheduling the Conference, advise the taxpayer or authorized resentative that only individuals the taxpayer has authorized in writing represent them may attend (unless the taxpayer will authorize other persons or will attend the Conference). ) IRS grants relief under section

of the Procedure and Regulations when the taxpayer provides sufficient evidence to establish that both the: a. Taxpayer acted reasonably and in good faith, b. The grant of relief will not prejudice the interests of the government. (

) A taxpayer is deemed to have acted reasonably and in good faith if they: a. Filed the request for relief before the IRS discovers the failure to make timely election. b. Inadvertently failed to make the election because of intervening events beyond the taxpayer’s control. c. Failed to make the election because, after exercising reasonable diligence, was unaware of the necessity for the election. d. Reasonably relied upon the IRS’s written advice, or e. Reasonably relied on a qualiﬁed tax professional, including a tax sional employed by the taxpayer, and the tax professional failed to or advise the taxpayer to make, the election. (

) Ordinarily, the government’s interests are treated as prejudiced and ordinarily the IRS won’t grant relief when tax years that would have been affected by election (had the taxpayer timely made it) are closed by the statute of limita- tions before the taxpayer receives a ruling granting relief. Plans Technical - Case Processing Procedures 7.1.6 page
See IRM 7.2.1 for detailed procedures EP closing agreements. This IRM, section 7.1.6.11, highlights some of the key procedures in IRM 7.2.1.

IRS uses closing agreements when there’s an advantage in having a case permanently and conclusively closed. In the EP rulings area, a taxpayer generally requests a closing agreement as a way to resolve a case that can’t be resolved by a favorable PLR, but the taxpayer can show it’s appropriate to provide relief from adverse tax consequences. In some cases, a taxpayer considers a closing agreement to resolve tax liability.

State in the introductory paragraph that we are seeking the Director’s agreement in recommending a closing agreement. Present the facts, a summary of the closing agreement, and explain why EP Technical is recommending the closing agreement. Leave the signature blocks blank for the group manager, the Manager, EP Technical, the Director, EP Rulings and Agreements and the Director, Employee Plans. Transmit the memo and the draft closing agreement with an action routing slip. Write the reviewer, the group manager, and the same names that are in the memo’s signature block on the action routing slip.

Prepare three execution copies of the closing agreement. Send three copies with a cover letter to the taxpayer or authorized repre- sentative. Explain that the taxpayer needs to sign all copies of the agreements and return them to the IRS with any sanction due. Keep a copy of the cover letter in the case ﬁle. (See IRM
, TE/GE Closing Agreements, Closing Agreements Originating in EP Technical, for instructions to the taxpayer, and IRM
for the proce- dures to execute closing agreements.)
